org.nlpcraft.model.intent

Class NCIntentSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.nlpcraft.model.intent.NCIntentSolver
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Serializable

    public class NCIntentSolver
extends Object
implements Serializable
    Main entry point for intent-based user input matcher.

    Intent solver is intended for simpler and more declarative implementation of NCModel.query(NCQueryContext) method. This is the main method in the data model and it is responsible for converting parsed user input into an action. It cannot be defined in the external JSON or YAML model definition and, therefore, has to be defined in the code. Although this method can be implemented manually by encoding the logic of parsing query context and its list of parsing variants - it is often more complex and error-prone than necessary.

    Intent solver is based on an idea of adding one or more user input templates, also known as intents, and letting the solver select the best matching intent for a given the user input. Each intent defines a pattern of the user input and associated action to take when that pattern is selected. While selecting the best matching intent the solver uses sophisticated NLP analysis and conversation context for anaphoras resolution. Among multiple detected intents the solver will always select the most specific one.

    There are two ways how you can create an intent solver and use it in the model:

    • Text-based intent DSL with @NCIntent, @NCIntentRef and @NCIntentTerm annotations.
    • Class-based intent DSL with manual integration.

    Intent DSL
    Pros
    Cons
    Text-based DSL
    • Simple annotation-based configuration.
    • Least amount of code to write.
    • Intent definition and its callback are co-located.
    • Limited to &&, || and ! combinators.
    • Intent definition is static.
    • User-defined predicates are not supported.
    Class-based DSL
    • The most flexible and powerful intent configuration.
    • Intent configuration can be dynamic.
    • Support for user-defined predicates.
    • Support for all built-in combinators: OR, NOT, AND, NAND, NOR, XOR, XNOR.
    • Limited compile-time check.
    • Intent solver should be created manually.
    • Callback and the intent definition are not co-located.

    Text-based intent DSL

    Using text-based intent DSL with @NCIntent, @NCIntentRef and @NCIntentTerm annotations is a preferred way to add intents to your model. It is the most concise and natural way to work with intents with only a few technical limitations. @NCIntent annotation defines an intent on the method serving as its callback. This annotation takes a string value that defines an intent via text-based intent DSL. This annotation can only be used on methods in NCModel subclass that is configured as data model class in data probe configuration - no other classes will be scanned for this annotation. When a model get deployed in the probe, the probe will scan model's class for this annotation. When found during the scan, each annotation will be compiled into an intent and added to the model's newly created NCIntentSolver instance which will act as an implementation for NCModel.query(NCQueryContext) method (note that model's existing NCModel.query(NCQueryContext) method implementation will be overridden, if any).

    @NCIntentTerm annotation marks callback parameter to receive term's tokens. This is a companion annotation to @NCIntnet and @NCIntnetRef annotations and can only be used for the parameters of the methods that are annotated with @NCIntnet. @NCIntentTerm takes a term ID as its only mandatory parameter and should be applied to callback method parameters to get the tokens associated with that term (if and when the intent was matched and that callback was invoked).

    Here's a Scala example of an intent defined using @NCIntent and @NCIntentTerm annotations: 

     @NCIntent("id=my_intent conv=false term(t1)={groups @@ 'grp' && ~MY_META @@ 'item'}? term(t2)={id == 'tok2'}*")
 def onMatch(
      ctx: NCIntentSolverContext,
      @NCIntentTerm("t1") t1Tok: Option[NCToken],
      @NCIntentTerm("t2") t2Toks: List[NCToken]): NCQueryResult) {
     ...
 }
    Here's an intent from Alarm Clock Java example: 
         @NCIntent("" +
         "id=alarm " +
         "term={id=='x:alarm'} " +
         "term(nums)={id=='nlpcraft:num' && ~NUM_UNITTYPE=='datetime' && ~NUM_ISEQUALCONDITION==true}[0,7]")
     private NCQueryResult onMatch(
         NCIntentSolverContext ctx,
         @NCIntentTerm("nums") List<NCToken> numToks
     ) {
     ...
     }
    See @NCIntent and @NCIntentTerm annotations for more details on text-based intent DSL.

    Class-based intent DSL

    While text-based intent DSL and annotations provide convenient and natural way to associate an intent with its callback the class-based intent DSL provides the ultimate flexibility and power for the intent creator:
    • Class-based intent DSL can define intents dynamically based on runtime model configuration.
    • Class-based intent DSL can define terms using user-defined Java predicates over NCToken instance and not limited to predefined operations only.
    The basic usage of class-based intent DSL intent consists of the following steps:
    • Create new intent solver instance.
    • Add one or more intents to the solver: addIntent(INTENT, Function)
    • Provide instance of the intent solver to the data model via NCModelAdapter.setSolver(NCIntentSolver) method.
    Here's the class diagram for class-based intent DSL. Note that text-based intent DSL gets compiled into these classes as well: 

     +---------------+    +-------------------+
 |  CONV_INTENT  |    |  NON_CONV_INTENT  |
 +-------+-------+    +----------+--------+
         |                       |
         |                       |
         |    +----------+       |
         +---^+  INTENT  +^------+
              +----+-----+
                   |
                   |
               +---o----+
               |  TERM |
               +---+----+
                   |
                   |
             +-----0-------+
       +----^+ /COMBINATOR/ |^---+-----------+------------+------------+-----------+----------+---------+
       |     +-----^-------+    |           |            |            |           |          |         |
       |                        |           |            |            |           |          |         |
       |                        |           |            |            |           |          |         |
  +----+---+                +---+---+   +---+---+   +----+---+   +----+---+   +---+---+  +---+--+  +---+---+
  |  RULE  |                |  AND  |   |  NOR  |   |  XNOR  |   |  NAND  |   |  XOR  |  |  OR  |  |  NOT  |
  +--------+                +-------+   +-------+   +--------+   +--------+   +-------+  +------+  +---+---+
    An intent is a collection of TERMs and a callback to invoke for when that intent is selected. Intents can be ordered or unordered, conversational and non-conversational. Additionally to INTENT class there are two special subclasses that provide convenient shortcuts for creating specific intents: CONV_INTENT and NON_CONV_INTENT. Term is a predicate on a semantic token either from the model or the built-in one, and it can represent one or more individual words in the user input, sequential or not. Few important notes:
    • Classes like TERM and RULE have multiple convenient shortcut constructors to shorten the DSL notation.
    • TERM can represent a complex match on a token beyond just matching on token ID. Employing logical combinators or user-defined predicate the TERM can encode a sophisticated matching logic.
    • All TERMs should be found in the input string for the intent to match. Term can be optional if its min quantifier is zero.
    • Built-in nestable combinators OR, NOT, AND, NAND, NOR, XOR, XNOR can group RULEs to form a sophisticated matching logic.
    • If multiple intents match - the system will pick the one with the most specific match.
    Here's Java example of using class-based intent DSL (similar to Time example): 
     NCTokenSolver solver = new NCTokenSolver(
      "time-solver",
      false,
      __ -> { throw new NCRejection("Seems unrelated (check city name)."); }
 );

 // Exactly one 'x:time' token without looking into conversation.
 solver.addIntent(
      new NON_CONV_INTENT("id == x:time"), // Term index 0.
      this::onLocalMatch
 );

 // Exactly one 'x:time' and one 'nlpcraft:geo' CITY token including conversation context.
 solver.addIntent(
      new CONV_INTENT(
          new TERM("id == x:time"), // Term index 0.
          new TERM("geo", new AND(  // Term ID is 'geo', index 1.
              "id == nlpcraft:geo",
              "~GEO_KIND == CITY"
          ))
      ),
      this::onRemoteMatch
 );
    See Also:
    INTENT, CONV_INTENT, NON_CONV_INTENT, RULE, OR, NOT, AND, NAND, XOR, XNOR, NOR, TERM, Serialized Form

    • Constructor Detail

      • NCIntentSolver

        public NCIntentSolver()
        Creates new default intent solver. Default solver has default null name, no multi-match and default not-found function that throws NCRejection exception. This is equivalent to: 
              this(null, false, null);

      • NCIntentSolver

        public NCIntentSolver(String name)
        Creates new named intent solver with given parameters and default not-found function. Default not-found function throws NCRejection exception with generic error message.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the solver (for informational purpose only).

      • NCIntentSolver

        public NCIntentSolver(String name,
                      Function<NCQueryContext,NCQueryResult> notFound)
        Creates new named intent solver with given parameters.
        Parameters:
        name - Name of the solver (for informational purpose only).
        notFound - Custom not-found function. This function will be called when no matching intent can be found for given sentence. If null, a default implementation will be used that throws NCRejection exception with generic error message.

    • Method Detail

      • addIntent

        public NCIntentSolver addIntent(NCIntentSolver.INTENT intent,
                                Function<NCIntentSolverContext,NCQueryResult> fun)
        Adds given intent and its callback function to this solver.
        Parameters:
        intent - Intent to add.
        fun - A callback function that will be called when given intent is found to be the best match.
        Returns:
        Returns this solver for call chaining.

      • addIntent

        public NCIntentSolver addIntent(String intentDsl,
                                Function<NCIntentSolverContext,NCQueryResult> fun)
        Adds given text-based intent DSL and its callback function to this solver.
        Parameters:
        intentDsl - Intent in text-based DSL. See NCIntent for more documentation.
        fun - A callback function that will be called when given intent is found to be the best match.
        Returns:
        Returns this solver for call chaining.

      • getIntents

        public List<NCIntentSolver.INTENT> getIntents()
        Gets all added intents.
        Returns:
        All intents.

      • getName

        public String getName()
        Gets solver name.
        Returns:
        Solver name.

      • solve

        public NCQueryResult solve(NCQueryContext ctx)
                    throws NCRejection
        Finds the best matching intent for given sentence and calls its callback function to get the final query result. If no matching intent is found a not-found function will be called, if provided. If not-found function wasn't provided, the NCRejection exception with default rejection message will be thrown.
        Parameters:
        ctx - Sentence's context to find the best match for.
        Returns:
        Query result.
        Throws:
        NCRejection
